conversation.text: Hello! Would you like to learn how to cook live lobster?
evidence: Live lobsters may be available in your grocery store

conversation.text: Yes, please!
Great! The first step is to buy live lobsters. You can get these from a local fishmonger or grocery store.
evidence: Live lobsters may be available in your grocery store, at your local fishmonge

conversation.text: Yes, I have lobsters now. How can I prepare them?
First, add water to a large pot, so that it reaches 3/4 volume. Bring to the boil with 2 tbsp coarse salt per litre
evidence: large pot ¾ full with water
bring the water to a quick boil.

conversation.text: It's boiling now.
Simply throw the live lobsters into the boiling water, headfirst, and put the lid on the pot.
evidence: plunge them headfirst into the boiling water.
Cover the pot with a lid

conversation.text: Wait, before that do I need to clean the lobsters?
This is not necessary, but if you like you can rinse them quickly under cold water.
Really? I remember when I prepared shrimps before, there are a lot to do such as removing tails...
Lobsters can be cooked and served whole, then you can remove the unwanted parts after it is presented nicely on the plate. Please see the 'How to Eat Lobster' tutorial later.
Okay, thanks! Let's move on!
How many pounds does your lobster weigh? This will affect the cooking time (each typically weighs between 1-2 pounds)
evidence: One-pound lobsters should cook for about 15 minutes, 1 ½-pound lobsters for 20 minutes, and 2-pound lobsters for 25 minutes

conversation.text: About 8 pounds.
Cook the lobsters for 15-25 mins. If your lobsters are each 1 pound, cook for 15 mins. If 2 pounds, cook for 25 mins
evidence: One-pound lobsters should cook for about 15 minutes, 1 ½-pound lobsters for 20 minutes, and 2-pound lobsters for 25 minutes.

conversation.text: So I need 25 minutes or more?
As soon as the lobsters' shells become bright red, they have finished cooking. What colour are they now?
evidence: The lobsters are finished cooking when their shells have turned bright red.

conversation.text: Red. Looks like they're ready lol.
Excellent! Take the lobsters out and put the on their backs to keep them moist. Then serve each whole, with some melted butter, a nutcracker to break the claws and a discard bowl.
evidence: set them on a plate on their backs to dry and cool.
small cup of melted butter, a nutcracker for cracking the claws, a lobster pick and a bowl for the discarded shells.

conversation.text: Cool! Thanks!
Hope you enjoyed the cooking guide. Bon Appetite!!

procedure.description: Live lobsters may be available in your grocery store, at your local fishmonger or if you're exceptionally fortunate enough to live in a lobster fishing area, right off the boat that caught them. Look inside the lobster tank for lobsters that seem healthy and active. Avoid lobsters that are too still or have holes or black marks on their shells.

procedure.summary: Fill a large pot ¾ full with water.
procedure.description: Add 2 tablespoons of coarse salt for each quart of water, and bring the water to a quick boil.

procedure.summary: Plunge the lobsters into the water.
procedure.description: One at a time, pick up the lobsters by the body and plunge them headfirst into the boiling water. Cover the pot with a lid. Do not allow the water to overflow. If there isn’t room in the pot for all the lobsters you bought, cook them in two or more batches.

Once the water has come to a boil again, begin timing the cooking of the lobsters. One-pound lobsters should cook for about 15 minutes, 1 ½-pound lobsters for 20 minutes, and 2-pound lobsters for 25 minutes. The lobsters are finished cooking when their shells have turned bright red. Remove them from the pot and set them on a plate on their backs to dry and cool. This keeps the juices in the lobsters. It’s important to time the cooking, since lobsters may turn red before they are fully done.

Place each lobster on a dinner plate for serving. Serve each lobster with a small cup of melted butter, a nutcracker for cracking the claws, a lobster pick and a bowl for the discarded shells. See How to Eat Lobster for a tutorial on which parts of the lobster are good to eat.
